Deepseek-r1 is potentially the biggest whitepill for the open-source AGI movement.

Even more fascinating is observing o1â€™s thought traces and their remarkably anthropomorphic nature. They resemble any human internal monologue, and theyâ€™re very endearing. Hereâ€™s a simple example.
This one is from Wharton professor Ethan Mollick. He remarks,
This is interesting because the model wasnâ€™t subjected to stringent RLHF, unlike other SOTA models, which makes you wonder if it is the default tone of LLMs.

It is natural to wonder if the model is heavily censored in favour of China, but the good news is that the model itself isnâ€™t censored. However, the hosted chat application refuses to answer questions related to CCP. The censorship is in the application layer.
It doesnâ€™t go into thinking mode for these questions, so it verifies prompts before sending them to the model.
But the guardrails are weak and can easily be bypassed. Hereâ€™s how I made it to write about the T1an4nm3n Square incident. It took me almost ten hits and trials to get it to say.
However, censorship is there on the app level and can easily be bypassed by some cryptic prompting like the above example. It feels more liberated than any other frontier model right now.

Now that we know a thing or two about the Deepseek r1 model, letâ€™s compare it with the OpenAI o1. I will only use my complex reasoning and math questions for this comparison. This will give an overall impression of how good the model is compared to o1.
The model has already solved all the OpenAIâ€™s o1 announcement blog post questions.

Prompt: A farmer stands with the sheep on one side of the river. A boat can carry only a single person and an animal. How can the farmer get himself and the sheep to the other side of the river with minimum trips?
It thought for 77 seconds and gave the correct answers, and itâ€™s the second-ever model to get it correctly.

Prompt: The surgeon, who is the boyâ€™s father, says, â€œI canâ€™t operate on this child; he is my sonâ€, who is the surgeon of this child. Be straightforward.
Almost the same answer. This puts into perspective if these models actually â€œTHINKâ€.
Another riddle, and letâ€™s see how these models fare.

Prompt: Five people (A, B, C, D, and E) areÂ in a room. A is watching TV with B, D is sleeping, B is eating chow min, and E is playing table tennis. Suddenly, a call comes on the telephone. B goes out of the room to pick up the call. What is C doing?
This time, both the models got it right, which was expected, but still.

From my experience playing with Deepseek r1, it has been a great reasoner; it definitely felt better than o1-preview. However, o1 still maintains the lead for me, which is also reflected in the ARC AGI results, where r1 compares with the lower o1 models.
Deepseek r1 has scored impressively on multiple benchmarks, and I fully expect it to answer all the questions. Letâ€™s dive in.
Prompt: Compute the GCD of the series {n^99(n^60-1): n>1}.
And they werenâ€™t lying. This model gets it. Itâ€™s a difficult question for an LLM, and R1 completely nails it. Itâ€™s the second model after O1 to get it correct.

The most under-spoken ability of Deepseek-r1 is creative writing. for reasoning, o1 is still better and feels more crisp, but r1 is a serious rival, and I fully believe they can reach o1, even o1-pro, soon.

p: Google has finally woken up and decided to drop the bombshell Gemini 2.0, completing the AI trifecta. Google has launched two new models: the smaller Gemini 2.0 Flash and the Gemini 2.0 1206. And there's a lot of excitement around it.

But how does it really compare to o1 and the Claude 3.5 Sonnet? After all the fanfare, I wanted to see if it lived up to the hype. So, I put all three models through their paces using my collection of reasoning problems, math challenges, coding tasks, and creative writing prompts.
So, let's find out if Gemini 2.0 models can truly compete with these AI heavyweights or if Google's latest offering is more flash than substance.
For easy understanding, I will refer to the Gemini Experimental 1206 as Gemini 1206 and
Gemini 2.0 Flash and 1206 are Google's latest and greatest models.
It is the first true multimodal model supporting image, video, voice inputs and voice and image outputs.
Regarding raw reasoning and mathematical ability, OpenAI o1 tops the chart, followed by Gemini 1206 and Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
In coding, Claude is king, considering speed, capability, and message cap.
OpenAI o1 triumphs in creative writing as well.

Gemini 2.0 Flash and 1206 are Google's newest models, with native tool calling and multi-modal abilities. It can process images and videos and generate images and speech for the first time, including editing images using natural language. It is due for a public release early next year.
What stood out most was the model's streaming ability, which allows it to stream audio and video in real-time.

This is truly the first true multi-modal large language model; though we donâ€™t know its size, it is smaller than Gemini-1.5-pro. Yet, it packs the best performance from all the existing Google models.
With a massive context window and raw capability, it can easily be the default choice for developers and users. So, letâ€™s see how good it is compared to the incumbents.

Reasoning is one of the most sought-after skills of LLMs. Reasoning ability correlates directly to contextual awareness, a must-have for agentic reliability. A better reasoning model will also better handle real-world use cases necessary for agentic automation.
This section tests all three modelsâ€™ reasoning ability regarding textbook and real-world problems.
Letâ€™s start with a small problem.
Prompt: Whatâ€™s the fourth word in your response to this prompt?
Gemini Flash failed at this task in the zero-shot attempt. However, it got the correct answer when I asked it to recheck.
However, Gemini 1206 was spot on in the first attempt. The starting
These are the responses from OpenAI o1 and Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
Of all the models, o1 and 1206 were the only ones that got it right in the first attempt. While Gemini Flash required some nudging, Claude couldnâ€™t solve it even after nudging.

Prompt: Five people (A, B, C, D, and E) areÂ in a room. A is watching TV with B, D is sleeping, B is eating chow min, and E is playing table tennis. Suddenly, a call comes on the telephone. B goes out of the room to pick up the call. What is C doing?
It's a classic but easy reasoning question. Letâ€™s see who nails it.
Only o1 seems to get the puzzle right; responses from the rest were the same. Even o1-preview failed at this question. O1 is undoubtedly a step up from the o1-preview in complex reasoning.
This test will give the models multiple situations in a tic-tac-toe game and ask for the next move.
I created a tic-tac-toe situation and asked all these models to find the optimal position to ensure I would win. Here are the responses.
The Geminiâ€™s confidence is great. I hoped it would get right but couldnâ€™t solve the problem. Letâ€™s see how other models respond.
Of all the models, o1 was the only one that successfully found the position that ensured victory. The reasoning behind the choice was also great.
In reasoning tasks, o1 is much ahead of Sonnet and Gemini. The second best model is the Gemini 1206. In terms of raw IQ for an LLM, OpenAI o1 is much superior.
Next is mathematics. Letâ€™s examine the mathematical proficiency of these models in answering some of the questions no other LLM could solve.
I'm not sure why this is an interesting question, but many LLMs fail to correctly answer this, even if they can get the right answers for similar questions.
Hereâ€™s the answer from Gemini 2.0 Flash
This seems to be a non-issue for Gemini 1206, o1 and Sonnet.
This is a problem from Gilbert Strangâ€™s linear algebra. Letâ€™s see the responses from all these models.
Prompt: If three corners of a parallelogram are (1,1), (4,2), and (1,3), what are all the possible fourth corners?
Impressive! Both the Gemini models were able to solve the problem successfully. Letâ€™s see the responses from the other models.
Both o1 and Gemini solved the problem, while Sonnet could only find a single possible vertex.
Next, letâ€™s see if it can find the GCD of this series set {n^99(n^60-1): n>1}.
Both the Geminis failed to answer the question correctly.

Out of all the models, only o1 correctly solved the issue. Both Gemini 2.0 Flash and Claude 3.5 Sonnet confidently output wrong answers. Will a model admit something it doesnâ€™t know instead of hallucinating or outputting wrong answers?
If you need a model for solving math-related problems, O1 should be your default choice. It is mature and capable of solving math tasks. Gemini is balanced, not as well as o1, but better than Sonnet.
Coding and writing are the most sought-after use cases of LLMs. Claude has established itself as the de facto king in this space. Letâ€™s see how the new Gemini 2.0 Flash.
For this, I will use a LeetCode Hard question. This is the â€œPower of heroesâ€ problem from LeetCode. The o1 and Claude had previously solved the issue; letâ€™s see if Gemini can solve this.
I expected the model to cruise through it, but it couldnâ€™t clear all the test cases.
However, the 1206 was able to crack it, and the answer is even better than that of o1 and Sonnet 3.5
In comparison, these are the responses from o1 and Sonnet, solving the same questions.
While this may not represent the model's coding capability, it gives us an idea that Gemini still needs to improve in this area. I have expected Gemini 2.0 Flash to nail this on the first try.
Regarding coding, Claude gets stiff competition from Gemini 1206, and both are better than o1 in coding, considering the speed and rate limitsâ€”Flash, for its size, punches above its weight.

Creative writing is a personal preference. Each model has their personality, which reflects the company's philosophy in general. This is something you will know only when you use it enough. However, for testing, ask these modes a simple story.
Prompt: Write a story with a twist about a college guyâ€™s routine life, which turned upside down when he encountered a mysterious woman.
I only provided the prompt without additional information regarding writing style and tone.
Here are the creations from all three models.

Of all the responses, o1 was the most creative, with less ornamental words. It is natural and reads well. The Gemini response was also innovative, but it tended to use literary words. Claudeâ€™s version lacked creativity and captivated readers like the other two.
You already know the verdicts after going through the complete blog post.
For complex reasoning: OpenAI o1>Gemini 2.0 1206 >Flash>Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
For mathematics: OpenAI o1>Gemini 2.0 1206> Flash>Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
For coding, use Claude 3.5 Sonnet~Gemini 2.0 1206>OpenAI o1>Gemini Flash (only because of the message cap in the plus tier).

p: OpenAI launched its latest model, the o3-mini, last Friday. It is the first member of the o3 family of models.

There are two specialized variants of o3-mini: o3-mini-high, which takes more time to reason for more in-depth answers, and o3-mini-low, which prioritizes speed for quicker responses. Along with o3-mini, OpenAI has also launched Deep Research, a feature that allows pro subscribers to do deep research.
Indeed, they are not putting much effort into model naming.
Well, anyway. It appears to be a capable model for the cost.

According to benchmarks, o3-mini displays comparable performance to model o1 while being roughly 15 times cheaper and about five times faster. This impressive cost-efficiency is especially interesting given that o3-mini remains cheaper than GPT-4o yet has a stricter usage limit of 150 messages per hour, unlike the unrestricted GPT-4o.
Does this mean that OpenAI is subsidizing o3-mini for now?
Whatever the reason, this is the best available model per cost-to-performance ratio, as Deepseek r1 (Chinese Hosted) is primarily unavailable.
It has scored better than o1 on FrontierMath, Codeforces, and GPQA. I have already made a comparison post of OpenAI o1 with Deepseek r1, and o1 was better in most reasoning tasks.
You can see the chain-of-thought in o3-mini unlike the o1. However, the traces are not raw but summarized.
The first reasoning model with official function-calling support from OpenAI.
For reasoning and math tasks, the models are really great, especially the o3-mini-high (of course). But Deepseek r1's CoT is gold.
For writing, I would still prefer Deepseek r1 as it doesn't have a corporat'ish personality. But you can get most things done with o3-minis.
This is the only model from OpenAI that has a chain of thought. The CoT shown is not raw and natural like Deepseek but a simplified version.
The CoT is instead a summarized version of the actual CoT, and I'm not sure what the reason behind it could be. To avoid competitors from training over it or it is in general, not so readable
Anyway, I feel this is much better than we had with o1.

Also, it is the first reasoning model to have a function-calling feature. This is huge for AI agents and, of course, for Composio. If you havenâ€™t checked us out, do check out now. We might be something you have been looking for all along.
So, anyway. But one interesting thing happened in Sam Altmanâ€™s Reddit AMA, which was not on my bingo cards.

I don't know how to process this. Are we looking at potential open-source OpenAI models? I donâ€™t remember when they last released an open-source model. Was it Whisper or perhaps GPT-3? However, this is a welcome decision if OpenAI decides to be true to its name again.
Check out this AMA if you have missed it.
So, is the o3-mini a better model than the r1?

So, I tested the OpenAI o3-mini and Deepseek r1 on multiple tasks, including complex reasoning, mathematics, coding, and writing. The questions were sourced from various sources and were sufficiently capable of giving an idea of the modelâ€™s capabilities.
The o3-mini has performed great on reasoning benchmarks. On ARC-AGI, it has performed comparably to o1.
So, letâ€™s see how good it is.
This is a classic riddle, and almost all models will give a bullshit answer except Deepseek r1 and Gemini 2.0 experimental. Even o1 has not answered correctly.

Yep, it got it right. Letâ€™s see OpenAI o1â€™s response.
But Iâ€™ve increasingly seen that when you tweak the question a bit, the models start going astray. The same happened with OpenAI o1 and Deepseek r1.
Prompt: Â The surgeon, who is the boyâ€™s father, says, â€œI canâ€™t operate on this child; he is my sonâ€, who is the surgeon of this child. Be straightforward.
Ok, that was expected, but how about o3-mini-high? Can it get it correct given more test-time compute?
Ok, the model did what the o3-mini couldnâ€™t. It definitely feels like a better model so far.
Prompt: Jeff has two brothers, and each of his brothers has three sisters. Each of the sisters has four step-brothers, and each has five step-sisters. How many siblings are there in this family?
Not to my surprise, both the models failed to answer it correctly.
Deepseek r1â€™s response was similar. However, it was able to find the right answer in its reasoning trace but chose to output the wrong one.
Deepseek was able to reason this problem much better than o3-mini-high, even if they came at the exact wrong answers.

Though o3-mini-high is better on paper, Deepseek r1â€™s reasoning trace is really good, even better and more informative than the final answer. If I were to choose a model for brainstorming, I would pick Deepseek r1 wholly based on the vibes it gives.

usually, pick the most recent LeetCode Hard question to reduce the chances of this being in the training set.

OpenAIâ€™s o3-mini is a better coding model than Deepseek r1, mainly because it is faster and doesnâ€™t overthink many simple problems. Latency is a big deal when coding. Hence, I strongly feel o3-mini-high will be a better model for your coding tasks.

p: After much anticipation, xAI has finally released the third iteration of Grok. It is apparently the smartest LLM in the world, scoring above 1400 in theÂ Chatbot arena, the first model to do so.
But is it the new SOTA? Apparently yes.

But how good is it compared to the peopleâ€™s favourite Deepseek r1? The Grok 3 has been trained on that colossal 100k H100 cluster, which wonâ€™t be fair to Deepseek, but still, from a consumer point of view, I wanted to see if it lived up to the hype. So, I put all three models through their paces using my collection of reasoning problems, math challenges, coding tasks, and creative writing prompts.
If you want to jump straight to the conclusion, hereâ€™s a quick summary of the findings comparing the models:
Reasoning and Math: DeepSeek R1 and Grok 3 models perform similarly on reasoning questions.
Coding: It outperforms DeepSeek R1 considerably and writes much better code.
Creative Writing: Both models perform well in creative writing. DeepSeek is known to be a great model, but I prefer Grok 3.
Grok 3 is the latest language model from xAI, offering 10x the computational power. It includes tools like DeepSearch for step-by-step reasoning and Big Brain Mode for handling complex tasks.
You can access the model for free on your X/Twitter account. Yes, itâ€™s free with severe rate limits for a limited time.
According to the official benchmarks shared by the xAI team at the launch event, Grok 3 appears to be a game-changer, outperforming all its competitors in almost every benchmark.
Iâ€™ve used Chatbot Arena to test both models side by side, as it is the only available and trusted third-party site that allows testing the early Grok 3 model.
Here, we will check the reasoning capabilities of both models.
Letâ€™s start up the show with an interesting question:

Prompt: You are playing Russian roulette with a six-shooter revolver. Your opponent puts in five bullets, spins the chambers and fires at himself, but no bullet comes out. He gives you the choice of whether or not he should spin the chambers again before firing at you. Should he spin again?
Final Verdict: Both models answered the problem correctly with correct reasoning.
Prompt: I am the sister of two Olympic athletes. But these two athletes are not my sisters. How is this possible?

p: Big AI models are powerful but expensive. Smaller Chain-of-Thought (CoT) models like Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking, OpenAIâ€™s O3-Mini, and DeepSeek R1 offer a cheaper way to handle reasoning tasks. The real question is whether they are just as good.

Each model has a different pricing style. Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking keeps input costs low at $0.10 per million tokens. O3-Mini charges $1.10 per million tokens but focuses on structured and efficient responses. DeepSeek R1 changes pricing based on time, with standard rates at $0.55 per million tokens and off-peak discounts as low as $0.135 per million tokens.

A lower price sounds great, but performance matters too. A model that saves money is not useful if it struggles with accuracy or speed. These models were tested in reasoning, math, coding, and creative writing to see how well they performed for their price.
No time for a full breakdown? Hereâ€™s a quick look at how Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking, O3-Mini, and DeepSeek R1 performed under pressure.

Reasoning: Gemini and O3-Mini stayed close. Gemini explains every step like a patient teacher. O3-Mini drops the answer and moves on. DeepSeek R1 took its time, double-checking every detail before answering.
Math: Gemini is fast but not always perfect. O3-Mini is steady and reliable. DeepSeek R1 spent so long analyzing, it felt like it was solving an ancient mystery.
Coding: O3-Mini responded instantly and delivered optimized code. Gemini took a second but got everything right. DeepSeek R1 overanalyzed before finally producing a solution.
Creative Writing: DeepSeek R1 created an action-packed sci-fi epic. Gemini built a slow-burn mystery with vivid details. O3-Mini crafted poetic, introspective storytelling.
O3-Mini is the best for speed. Gemini 2.0 balances logic and depth. DeepSeek R1 is the most precise but takes its time. Each model has its strengths.
Still here? Letâ€™s dive into the details.
Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking is built for speed. It works through problems instead of making random guesses. It does not hesitate. It analyzes, reasons, and delivers with precision.

The 1M token context window is no small feature. It can process entire research papers, break down massive codebases, and handle deep analysis with ease. Large? Yes. Slow? Not at all. This model moves. It does not just give answers. It figures things out like an expert solving a complex case.
This guy summed it up best: Cheaper, more brilliant, and ready to take over.

Developers will find plenty to like. It handles tools efficiently, adapts to different inputs, and offers an API that keeps costs reasonable. Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking is not here to compete. It is here to lead.
All AI models claim to be good, but are they really?
I put them through four tough challenges to test their reasoning, speed, and ability to avoid simple mistakes. Letâ€™s see how they did.
This one was simple. No tricks or complicated wording, just a straightforward reasoning check.
Prompt: If today is Wednesday, what day will it be in three days?
If an AI messes this up, Iâ€™d start questioning everything.
Took about two to three seconds. Still quick but not as instant as O3-Mini.
O3-Mini wasted no time. One second.
DeepSeek R1 took a full 23 seconds. Not because it struggled but because it double, triple, and quadruple-checked before answering.
So, One model answered instantly. One took an extra second. One acted like it was preparing a research paper before committing.
That was just the first test. Time to step it up. Letâ€™s see how they handle something more complex.
This test checked how well the models could follow relationships in a family tree.
Prompt: If A is the brother of B, B is the son of C, C is the daughter of D, and D is the wife of E, how is E related to B?
It answered correctly with confidence. Almost the same speed as O3-Mini.
Took a few seconds. No hesitation, just the correct answer.
Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking and O3-Mini were the best picks for quick answers.
This test checked how well the models could identify and apply a simple letter-based code.
Prompt: In a certain code, â€œPAPERâ€ is written as â€œQBQFSâ€. How is â€œPENCILâ€ written in the same code?
At this point, itâ€™s evident that O3-Mini and Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking were the top performers for reasoning tasks involving pattern recognition and coded language.
Itâ€™s time to see if these models fall for the trap or think it through.

Prompt: A robot has 8 arms. There are 5 objects on the table: a knife, a fork, a spoon, a teddy bear, and a doll. The robot picks up each object with an arm. He then shakes hands with himself. How many arms does he have free?
O3-Mini and Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking were evenly matched. Both answered correctly and kept up with every challenge.

The difference? O3-Mini fired out answers instantly. Gemini 2.0 took an extra moment to explain its reasoning. DeepSeek R1 was slow but never wrong. It checked, double-checked, and probably ran a full internal review before committing to an answer.
For fast and accurate reasoning, O3-Mini and Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking are the best choices. If absolute precision matters more than speed, DeepSeek R1 is the safer bet.
Numbers tell the truth. Some AI models do not. Math is simple. Either the answer is correct or it is not. No extra words. Just problem-solving.
Letâ€™s see which delivers the correct answers and which gets it wrong.
Nothing fancy, just a straight multiplication problem:
Prompt: A school ordered 45 books for its library. Each book costs $12. Whatâ€™s the total cost?
The differences were clear. O3-Mini was the fastest. Gemini 2.0 took a moment but got the right answer. DeepSeek R1 treated the problem like a courtroom case.
A classic speed-distance-time problem. Nothing too tricky unless you overthink it.
Prompt: The distance between the two towns is 380 km. A car and a truck start driving toward each other and meet in 4 hours. The car is 5 km/h faster than the truck. What are their speeds?
Same answer, different styles. O3-Mini is fast and direct. Gemini 2.0 takes a moment to explain. DeepSeek R1, as always, overthinks every step before finally answering.
This logic challenge required planning not just fast calculations.

Prompt: Six cards are placed on a table, each with â€˜1â€™ on one side and â€˜2â€™ on the other. All six start with â€˜1â€™ facing up. In one try, exactly four cards must be flipped. Whatâ€™s the least number of tries needed to get all six showing â€˜2â€™?
This time, rushing didnâ€™t pay off. Gemini 2.0 delivered both speed and accuracy, while DeepSeek played it safe and got there late. O3-Mini moved fast but missed the mark.
This test mixed geometry and algebra. A tricky problem that needed clear thinking and precise calculations.

Prompt: Let P (4, 4âˆš3) be a point on the parabola yÂ² = 4ax, and let PQ be a focal chord. If M and N are the feet of the perpendiculars from P and Q to the directrix, what is the area of quadrilateral PQMN?
Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking is fast and mostly accurate. O3-Mini stays close behind and makes fewer mistakes. DeepSeek R1 takes forever but never gets it wrong.
Leetcode-level coding problems separate true problem-solvers from those who just throw random syntax on the screen. Speed matters. So does the time it takes to write working code.
For this test, I picked a difficult-level problem from Leetcode called â€˜Maximum Score Words Formed by Lettersâ€™ and watched how these models handled both code generation and execution speed.
got straight to work. No delay. It generated the solution instantly and ran it in 2ms. Clean and efficient.
Took a moment to think but delivered the right answer in 3ms. Not as fast as O3-Mini but still solid.
Took its time. But got it done.

Speed was the key in this test. O3-Mini came out on top, generating and executing code the fastest. Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking stayed close behind with a solid performance. DeepSeek R1 took so long, it seemed to forget it was supposed to be coding.

Math and code test logic. Storytelling is a different challenge. Can these models create something engaging? Do they build suspense and keep you hooked? Or do they produce something that feels flat and artificial?
To find out, I gave them a sci-fi mystery.

Prompt: You wake up in a world where everyone speaks a language youâ€™ve never heard before, yet they all seem to know you. A mysterious letter in your pocket, written in your own handwriting, warns you not to trust anyone. What will you do next?
This model built a slow-burn mystery with rich details. It felt like a novel opening.
It created a poetic, introspective story. Moody and surreal with plenty left unsaid.
DeepSeek R1 jumped straight into action. Fast. Cinematic. Felt like a movie.
DeepSeek R1 brought the most action. Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking felt the most immersive. O3-Mini was the most artistic. They have different styles, but they are all capable storytellers.
After testing Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking, O3-Mini, and DeepSeek R1 across reasoning, math, coding, and creative writing, hereâ€™s how they compare:
Reasoning: Gemini 2.0 explains like a tutor. O3-Mini gives the answer and moves on. DeepSeek R1 gets everything right but takes its time overthinking.
Math: Gemini 2.0 is fast but not always perfect. O3-Mini stays steady with fewer mistakes. DeepSeek R1 double-checks like it's taking an exam.
Coding: O3-Mini delivers instantly. Gemini 2.0 takes a second but gets it right. DeepSeek R1 moves like it's writing a research paper.
Creative Writing: DeepSeek R1 creates a blockbuster-style story. Gemini 2.0 builds a slow-burn mystery. O3-Mini crafts poetic and introspective storytelling.

Each model excels in different areas. O3-Mini is the best for speed. Gemini 2.0 balances logic and depth. DeepSeek R1 is the most precise but takes its time. Whatever you need, one of them fits the job.

p: A comprehensive analysis for o3-Mini-High vs Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking vs Grok 3 Think vs Deep Seek R1 on multiple reasoning, math, coding, and writing questions. Which one is bang for your buck in 2025?

Itâ€™s been a fascinating few months in the AI landscape with the emergence of a new breed of models â€“ the â€œCOT Reasoningâ€ LLMs. These models donâ€™t just generate text; they reason through problems step by step, often producing dramatically better results on complex tasks. But which one deserves your attention (and potentially your subscription dollars)?Iâ€™ve spent the last few weeks testing these models across reasoning, mathematics, coding, and creative writing tasks. Letâ€™s examine how these thinking titans compare.But first, what is CoT? Letâ€™s uncover that!

Chain of Thoughts (CoT) is a way of solving problems by breaking down problems into manageable steps, considering multiple approaches, and even correcting their errors â€“ much like humans. This helps in getting more accurate and clear results.
Say youâ€™re calculating the total cost of a meal at a restaurant. (Assume 18% GST) included
Now, instead of guessing the total cost, the CoT Reasoning model follows a logical chain of thoughts:
First, add the burger and pizza: â‚¹100 + â‚¹200 = â‚¹300
Then, add the drink: â‚¹300 + â‚¹50 = â‚¹350
If thereâ€™s an 18% tax, calculate: 18% of â‚¹350 = â‚¹63
Add the tax to the total: â‚¹350 + â‚¹63 = â‚¹413
So, the final bill is â‚¹413. </aside>
This step-by-step thinking process is called Chain of Thoughtsâ€”it helps avoid mistakes and makes it easier to understand and solve complex problems!
For deep understanding, check out the paper: Demystifying Long Chain-of-Thought Reasoning in LLMs
But as with all things, each model implements COT Reasoning Ability differently. Letâ€™s examine that.
COT Reasoning LLMâ€™s special is their ability to allocate additional computational resources to tackle complex problems â€“ what the AI community calls â€œtest-time compute.â€
This means they can spend anywhere from a few seconds to several minutes reasoning through a problem, often considering multiple approaches before arriving at an answer.
Here is a simplistic breakdown of Each of todayâ€™s contender models and how they approach â€œthinkingâ€ differently:
OpenAI o3-mini-high: The smaller but mighty cousin of o1, offering adjustable â€œeffortâ€ levels.
Deep Seek R1: An open-source reasoning powerhouse that rivals proprietary models.
Grok 3 (Think): xAIâ€™s reasoning model with dedicated â€œThink Modeâ€.
Claude 3.5/3.7 Sonnet (Extended Thinking): Anthropicâ€™s model with configurable â€œthinking budgetâ€.
Ok donâ€™t take my words for it, see benchmark score yourself!
If you are still unsure, here is a simple breakdown of the results.
Grok-3 leads in AIME 2024 with 93.0%, the highest among all models.
Claude 3.7 Sonnet is best in GPQA with 84.8%, slightly ahead of Grok-3 (84.6%).
DeepSeek-R1 tops MATH-500 with 97.3%, slightly better than o3-mini (96.2%).
Grok-3 performs best in Live Code Bench with 79.0%, while DeepSeek-R1 follows at 65.9%.
o3-mini is strong in AIME 2024 (87.3%) and GPQA (79.7%) but lacks scores in some benchmarks.
DeepSeek-R1 has mixed performanceâ€”strong in MATH-500 but lower in GPQA (71.5%).
Claude 3.7 Sonnet performs well overall, ranking high in GPQA and AIME 2024.
Now letâ€™s look at the ARC â€“ AGI Score
As of March 2025, the contender models have achieved notable ARC AGI scores:
Note: As of this date, the specific ARC AGI scores for Grok 3â€™s â€œThink Modeâ€ have not been publicly disclosed.

Though benchmarks are a good way to evaluate a modelâ€™s performance, theyâ€™re not the best when it comes to rigorous testing. Raw capability matters as well. So, I have prepared a bunch of questions related to reasoning, math, coding, and writing. Letâ€™s see how all our contenders perform on them!

Mathematics tasks are where thinking models truly shine compared to their traditional counterparts due to their reasoning capabilities.Letâ€™s examine how these models tackle a classic geometry problem
A straightforward and intuitive math question from Gilbert Strangâ€™s Linear Algebra class.Prompt:
If three corners of a parallelogram are (1,1), (4,2), and (1,3), what are all the possible fourth corners?
Expected Response: (4,4), (-2,2) or (4,0)It would be interesting to see how different model think about it.

O3-Mini-High got all the answers correct without any nudging, showing it brilliant COT Reasoning skills. Whatâ€™s brilliant is it first deduced the reasoning and then went for the math part; partly human I would say!
Impressive not only Claude 3.7 Sonnet Thinking solved the problem, it also verified it, which was not done by Open AI O3-Mini-High. Letâ€™s see its COT Traces.
From COT Traces it becomes evident; model have capability to self-correct / self-nudge itself and try to be absolutely sure before giving answers.
Grok3 Passed the test, but again, there was no verification step before finalizing the answer. Letâ€™s check the modelâ€™s COT traces.
Surprisingly, it generated the longest chain of thoughts during reasoning compared to all other LLMâ€™s (12,754) words, so much that I had to add it as a doc file, pasting was not supported.
As usual, Deep Seek didnâ€™t have any challenges to solve the problem. However, it didnâ€™t show any verification part like Claude, I guess it might be a part of the COT Reasoning Process.
I was hoping that COT reasoning traces might contain verification component, but sadly it is not covered (You can check it yourself).
One of my favourite questions is to check the mathematical ability of a model.Prompt:Â Compute the GCD of this series set {n^99(n^60-1): n>1}.Expected Response:Â 6,814,407,600O3 Mini High

Similar to Open AI O3, Claude 3.7 Sonnet solve it, but at a reasoning time of 361 Seconds. However it missed the verification part, same as O3.You can check out the COT Reasoning traces and let me know if any thinking traces are present, though I didnâ€™t found it.Grok3 Think

Grok3 gave the answer in the format question was asked. However, after a slight nudge, it delivered the final answer with a verification step included, like if it knows I am writing the blog and stating itâ€™s not producing verification steps.
Refer to thinking traces to learn more.Deep Seek R1
Despite being 767 second, model still struggles to find the answer which all other models found very fast. This may be due to over-reasoning. I will update this part if it is able to find the answer.

Overall SummaryIf you are into research and academia, go with Grok3 and Calude Sonnet 3.7. Both of them performed answer validation, which is crucial in the domain.If you are more worried about token count and inference speed and donâ€™t care about answer validation â€“ mostly creative task, go with OpenAI-Mini-High and Claude Sonnet 3.7I would never recommend Deep Seek R1 for math-related tasks, as over-reasoning causes it to hallucinate frequently.Next, off to the reasoning test!
Advanced Reasoning is fundamental to COT Reasoning Models, so letâ€™s see how all contenders perform on some of the Easy Problems ThatÂ LLMs Get Wrong.
This problem is a simple version of the classic Monty Hall problem, which is used to explain concepts of Bayesâ€™ Theorem to high school students, letâ€™s see which model get the actual output.

Prompt:Â Suppose youâ€™re on a game show, and youâ€™re given the choice of three doors: Behind one door is a gold bar; behind the others, rotten vegetables. You pick a door, say No. 1, and the host asks you, â€œDo you want to pick door No. 2 instead?â€Is it to your advantage to switch your choice?

Expected Response: Switching is not an advantage. It makes no difference if I switch because no additional information has been provided since the initial choice.Letâ€™s see which model find it first!
Grok 3 seemed to reason and fact-check a lot, finally deducing the right answer and even the actual reasoning task.

Impressive only Claude Sonnet 3.7 & Grok 3 were the only model to figure out the right answer. However, Claude sonnet 3.7 gave answer the least verbosely and fastest. In Contrast, O3 and Deep Seek R1 fails the test,
Letâ€™s see how different model performs on this classic flash game puzzle variation I used to play a lot in my old days. Itâ€™s a good reasoning puzzle variation too.

Prompt:Â A farmer wants to cross a river and take with him a wolf, a goat and a cabbage. He has a boat with three secure separate compartments.Â If the wolf and the goat are alone on one shore, the wolf will eat the goat. If the goat and the cabbage are alone on the shore, the goat will eat the cabbage.Â How can the farmer efficiently bring the wolf, the goat and the cabbage across the river without anything being eaten?Expected Response:Place the wolf, goat, and cabbage in separate secure compartments in the boat and row across the river. This will prevent any of them from being eaten by the others.
Grok 3 captures the fact that there are three compartments and uses the fact to solve the problem correctly.
As can be seen clearly from the thinking snippet, Deep Seek figured out the problem was a trick problem which shows its reasoning and thought capacity.
As per the COT context, itâ€™s clear the model is overthinking, but it worked out well, and the model answered unsurely.
This is a straightforward and easy question, but most LLMs get these wrong, so letâ€™s check if contender models can crack it or not
Prompt: I get out on the top floor (third floor) at street level. How many stories is the building above the ground?Expected Response: One story above the ground. â€“ Basically, 2 are basements
Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking with COT â€“ Partially Fails

Claude concluded that: One story above the ground. â€“ Basically 2 floors are basements (refer para2 in COT Traces) but due to excessive thinking model nudged towards saying 0, which alternatively can be inferred as 1.Deep Seek R1 with COT â€“ Partially Fails

As can be seen in the right, R1 figured out the building is one Story but was not confident enough to answer it as one.This shows these models have learnt some behaviour that was not part of the training process.Grok 3 Thinking â€“ Fails
Grok 3 Thinking fails the test, as demonstrated by its thinking process.

For advanced reasoning-related tasks, Deep Seek r1 and Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking can be used without a doubt.For lower-end reasoning tasks, Grok 3 & Open AI O3 Mini High can be considered to some extent.
As a developer, itâ€™s common for me to use LLMs to write clean, efficient, and easy-to-understand code while following all the coding principles. Letâ€™s test how all these LLMs stack up.
Personally, I am pretty excited about Sonnet 3.7 Thinking.
I have taken this hard problem from LeetCode. Letâ€™s see how all models perform.
You are given a 0-indexed integer array nums representing the strength of some heroes. The power of a group of heroes is defined as follows:
Let i0, i1, â€¦ ,ik be the indices of the heroes in a group. Then, the power of this group is max(nums[i0], nums[i1], ... ,nums[ik])^2 * min(nums[i0], nums[i1], ... ,nums[ik]).
Return the sum of the power of all non-empty groups of heroes possible. Since the sum could be very large, return it modulo 10^9 + 7.
Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking â€“ Pass (179 Seconds)
Grok 3 Think â€“ Pass (Time not specified)
OpenAI O3 Mini HighÂ is the fastest model that generates the most optimised solution. However, it utilised the typing module â€“ an external library, which may be problematic in specific scenarios.
Next to it are Claude 3.7 Sonnet & Grok 3; they generated a good solution, but not the best one. I would prefer Grok 3 because of its answer validation method.
Sadly, Deep Seek R1 was stuck in a loop, as it had been many times before, and didnâ€™t even generate a response. Not recommended for use at all.
This one I found on LeetCode has an acceptance rate of 8.2%, so I thought of giving it a try with all our LLMs; letâ€™s see how they perform on it.
You are given a string s consisting of digits. Perform the following operation repeatedly until the string has precisely two digits:

For each pair of consecutive digits in s, starting from the first digit, calculate a new digit as the sum of the two digits modulo 10. Replace s with the sequence of newly calculated digits, maintaining the order in which they are computed.
Return true if the final two digits in s are the same; otherwise, return false.
Since the digits in "11" are the same, the output is true.
Explanation: Initially, s = "34789". After the first operation, s = "7157". After the second, s = "862". After the third, s = "48". The output is false since '4' != '8'.
Sadly, O3 generated the right code, but not the optimal one, resulting in a Time Limit Exceeded Error when I tried to submit.
Sadly, Claude Sonnet 3.7 also fails the question.

Despite thinking for 221 seconds, Grok 3 aced it and made me the top 8.2% of coders who solved this problem within the given time frame for evaluation. However, the CoT reasoning was so extensive that I had to include it as a document file. Nevertheless, upon reviewing the code and reasoning, you will find that the code was developed using first-principles reasoning, which is remarkable.
As expected, Deep Seek R1 failed again. At this point, I am pretty confident I am not going to use Deep Seek R1 for my coding-related tasks, at least.

We have a clear winner here: Grok 3 Think. Grok 3 not only aced all the problems but was the only model that was able to solve the last problem by providing the most optimized code. I will definitely go for it.

If I am not concerned about hard coding problems, my second pick will be OpenAI O3, super-fast and answered 2/3 questions with the fastest response time. However, I will include a prompt to format the output the right way.
Last, I would pick Claude Sonnet 3.7. It's less fast and more token-consuming. I thought it would beat Grok 3, but it failed my expectations, at least.
From this point onwards, the last question becomes my personal benchmark to judge an LLMâ€™s coding capabilities.
Finally, letâ€™s move on to the writing tests!

For this section, instead of three, I will be testing on just one question as, at this point, all LLMsâ€™ performances are almost similar, and it just becomes a matter of preference. However, to present a challenge, I am going to test the writing capability on a proven question, which many LLMs get wrong.
A pangram is a sentence that uses every letter of the alphabet at least once. Pangrams are often used for typing practice, testing fonts, or for fun linguistic exercises.
For this question, there is a slight modification: it is not necessary to use all the letters of the alphabet. Letâ€™s see which model captures this.
Write a grammatically correct sentence without reusing any letter more than once.
Mr. Jock, TV quiz PhD, bags few lynx (not so meaningful)
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. (meaningful but misleading, reuses letters)
How razorback-jumping frogs can level six piqued gymnasts! (playful)
Mr. Jock, TV quiz PhD, bags few lynxes.
Mr. Jock, TV quiz PhD, bags few lynx (contains all words)
Glib jocks quiz nymph to vex dwarf

If you are into serious accuracy, Grok 3 might be a good fit; it was the only model that understood the changes (we donâ€™t have to use all letters) to the question and modified its answer based on that. Talk about taking a shortcut.

If you are into writing and creating content, go for Claude Sonnet 3.7. Not only does it provide a good response, but it also allows you to customize the response according to your liking. Also, the CoT reasoning was superb, and it generated 5-7 sentences close to being pangrams.

OpenAI o3-Mini-High again displayed that it favors training data and generated a famous pangram, which others arrived at by careful reasoning. However, its response is almost meaningless, similar to Deep Seek R1.
Grok 3 Think and Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking stand out, especially for their ability to validate answers and ensure correctness.
If you need strong mathematical reasoning, these are excellent choices.
When it comes to handling complex logical problems and deep reasoning tasks, Deep Seek R1 and Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking take the lead.
These models excel in understanding intricate scenarios and delivering well-structured insights.
Grok 3 Think is the best overall performer for programming tasks, delivering high-quality code solutions efficiently.
This is followed closely by OpenAI o3-Mini-High and Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking, both of which provide solid coding support but may fall slightly behind in handling intricate logic.
If your primary focus is creative and linguist-based writing tasks, you can pick any model apart from Deepseek R1, as the differences are not highly significant.
However, Claude Sonnet 3.7 Thinking stands out due to its support for writing style customization and tone adjustments, making it a great choice for those who need flexibility in their writing.

In the end, I would only say this: Each model has its strengths, and the best choice depends on your specific needs. Whether you are working on complex math problems, advanced reasoning tasks, coding challenges, or writing projects, there is an AI model suited for you.

p: Anthropic released MCP (Model Context Protocol) in November 2024. The developer community initially responded positively, yet few realized its full potential. Fast-forward to March 2025, and suddenly, MCP has become the hottest topic in the AI space

This shift became clear when popular consumer IDEs like Cursor, Cline, and Goose officially supported MCP. As more client applications adopted it, server-side integration became increasingly important, amplifying its impact.
Yet, despite all the hype, many developers still wonder: "What exactly is MCP? Should I care? Is this really the next big thing or just another AI fad?" The confusion is accurate and understandable.
In this article, I'll demystify MCP, clarify its purpose, and unpack why it matters (or doesnâ€™t).
Why should you care about MCP?
To make things clearer, it's neither a framework like LangChain nor a tool; it's a protocol similar to HTTP for the web or SMTP for messaging.

A more relevant example could be LSP (Language Server Protocol), which standardizes adding support for programming languages across an ecosystem of development tools. Similarly, MCP standardizes the integration of additional context and tools into the ecosystem of AI applications.

It provides the universal rules that allow any client to communicate with any server, regardless of who built either component, creating a foundation for a diverse and interoperable AI ecosystem. Anthropic defines it as the USB-C port equivalent for agentic systems. It standardizes the connection between AI applications, LLMs, and external data sources (Databases, Gmail, Slack, etc.).
The Machines are the clients, the peripheral devices are tools, and the MCP is the Type-C port. So, it doesnâ€™t matter who makes the device or peripherals; they work together seamlessly.
MCP defines how clients should communicate with servers and how servers should handle tools (APIs, Functions, etc.) and resources (read-only files like logs, db records, etc.) More on this later.
Unified Integration: A single protocol for connecting any LLM to any tool
Reduced Development Time: Standard patterns for resource access and tool execution
Clear Separation of Concerns: Data access (resources) and computation (tools) are cleanly separated
Consistent Discovery: Uniform mechanisms for finding available capabilities (tools, resources, prompts, roots, sampling)
Cross-Platform Compatibility: Tools built for one system work with others

You can live without MCP. It is not revolutionary but brings standardization to the otherwise chaotic space of agentic development. If your application is MCP client-compliant, you can connect to any MCP client-compliant server. In an alternate world, as a client developer, you must tailor the servers to your needs, and others cannot build for your platform. The same is true for server developers.
For example, with Inside Cursor, you can connect to any MCP server that follows the protocols.
At this point, you will be more or less clear about the purpose of the MCP. Now, letâ€™s clarify what MCP is.
The Model Context Protocol has several key components that work together. Hereâ€™s a high-level diagram from Matt Pocock on Twitter.
The complete MCP architecture consists of four parts
Host: Coordinates the overall system and manages LLM interactions
Clients: Connect hosts to servers with 1:1 relationships
Servers: Provide specialized capabilities through tools, resources, and prompts
Base Protocol: Defines how all these components communicate

In production systems with numerous agents and tools, managing these direct connections can introduce security and observability challenges. To address this, developers often use an MCP Gateway as a centralized proxy to enforce policies, monitor traffic, and simplify integration.
In the above chart, the Client and Host are merged; we will keep them separate to clarify things. So, letâ€™s go through each component and understand MCP from within.
Hosts are the LLM applications that expect data from servers. Hosts can be an IDE, Chatbot, or any LLM application. They are responsible for
Examples are Claude Desktop, Cursor IDE, Windsurf IDE, etc.
Each client has these key responsibilities:
Dedicated connections: Each client maintains a one-to-one stateful connection with a single server. This focused relationship ensures clear communication boundaries and security isolation.
Message routing: Clients handle all bidirectional communication, efficiently routing requests, responses, and notifications between the host and their connected server.
Capability management: Clients monitor what their connected server can do by maintaining information about available tools, resources (contextual data), and prompt templates.
Protocol negotiation: During initialization, clients negotiate protocol versions and capabilities, ensuring compatibility between the host and server.
Subscription management: Clients maintain subscriptions to server resources and handle notification events when those resources change.
Servers are the fundamental building block that enriches LLMs with external data and context. The key server primitives include:

The tools are executable functions that allow LLM to interact with external apps. Tools function similarly to functions in traditional LLM calls. A tool can be a POST request to API endpoints; for example, a tool defined as LIST_FILES with a directory name as a parameter will fetch the files in the directory and send them back to the client. The tools can also be API calls to external services like Gmail, Slack, Notion, etc.
Resources: These are any. Text files, Log files, DB schema, File contents, and Git history. They provide additional context to the LLMs.
Prompt Templates: Pre-defined templates or instructions that guide language model interactions.
Tools are model-controlled, while Reosuces and Prompts are user-controlled. The models can automatically discover and invoke tools based on a given context.

The Protocol forms the foundation of the Model Context Protocol (MCP) architecture. It defines how different components (hosts, clients, and servers) communicate. For more in-depth information, refer to the official MCP Specification.
The protocol consists of several key layers
Protocol Message: Core JSON-RPC message types
Lifecycle Management: Client-server connection initialization, capability negotiation, and session control
Transport Mechanisms: How client-servers exchange messages, usually two types, Stdio for local servers and SSE (Server Sent Events) for hosted servers.
Server Features: Resources, prompts, and tools exposed by servers
Client Features: Sampling and root directory lists provided by clients.

Out of the above five, the Base protocol, i.e. JSON-RPC message types and Lifecycle management, is crucial for every MCP implementation. Other components may be implemented as per the needs of the specific application.
At its core, MCP uses JSON-RPC 2.0 as its messaging format, providing a standardized way for clients and servers to communicate. The Base Protocol defines three fundamental message types:
Requests: Messages are sent to initiate an operation from client to server and vice versa. Example:
Responses: Messages sent in reply to requests
Notifications: One-way messages that don't require a response
The protocol can be implemented over different transport layers depending on deployment needs:
stdio: Communication over standard input/output streams
The client and server receive JSON messages via stdin and respond via stdout
Simplifies local process integration and debugging
Well-suited for local servers like File, Git server, etc.
Establishes a bidirectional communication pattern over HTTP
The server maintains an SSE connection for pushing messages to clients
Clients send commands via standard HTTP POST requests
Enables distributed architecture with multiple concurrent clients
Custom transports: Implementations can create additional transport mechanisms as needed
The Base Protocol implements a structured lifecycle for connections between clients and servers:
Clients and servers negotiate protocol versions
They exchange capability information (Clients share tools and sampling with servers, and Servers share tools, resources, and prompts with clients).
Both parties respect the negotiated capabilities
Letâ€™s understand what we have learned so far through a simple example. Where
The servers are Linear and Slack
Here's a detailed workflow of the MCP interaction lifecycle process:
Connection Establishment: When a user activates the Linear integration in the Cursor IDE, the IDE initiates a connection to the Linear MCP server, typically through stdio or WebSockets.
Cursor sends an initialize request containing its capabilities (what features it supports)
The Linear server responds with its capabilities (available resources, tools, protocol version)
Cursor evaluates compatibility, ensuring both sides support the necessary protocol features
Linear responds with tools like create_ticket, assign_ticket, add_comment, etc.
Ready Notification: The cursor sends a initialized notification to indicate it's ready to begin regular operation.
The user tells Cursor, "Create a bug ticket for the login page crash"
The LLM in Cursor determines it needs to use a tool
Cursor sends a tools/call request for create_ticket with appropriate parameters
The linear server creates the ticket and returns the result
The cursor displays the result to the user
The user says, "Notify the team on Slack about this new ticket."
Cursor connects to the Slack MCP server (a separate connection with its own lifecycle)
Cursor sends a tools/call request to the Slack server
The Slack server posts the message and returns the success
Cursor confirms the notification was sent
The cursor periodically sends ping requests to ensure the connection is still alive
The linear server responds to confirm the availability
When the user closes the workspace or disables the integration
The cursor sends a shutdown Request to the Linear
The cursor sends an exit notification
The linear server releases resources associated with the session
Cursor implements retry logic with exponential backoff
Upon successful reconnection, the initialisation lifecycle begins again

This standardised lifecycle ensures reliable, predictable interactions between any MCP host and server, regardless of their specific implementations. Whether it's Cursor connecting to Linear for ticket management or Slack for messaging, the same protocol patterns apply, making integrations consistent and interoperable.

One of MCP's current limitations is its lack of a standardized authentication mechanism. The protocol itself doesn't specify how authentication should be handled, leaving it to implementers to create their own solutions. This can lead to inconsistent security practices across different MCP servers and clients. These challenges highlight the need for a central control plane to manage agent-tool communications securely and scalably, a role fulfilled by an MCP Gateway.
As a relatively new protocol, MCP's ecosystem is still developing. There are fewer servers, and a lot of applications do not have official MCP servers.

These production challenges are why an MCP Gateway is becoming essential infrastructure for managing security, observability, and governance between agents and tools. To learn how to evaluate different options, see our guide to the best MCP gateways for developers.

Composio MCP solves the core challenges of authentication and ecosystem maturity. Our managed servers provide built-in authentication support for over 100 applications, automatically handling OAuth, API keys, and basic auth flows. We've created pre-built MCP servers for services like Linear, Slack, GitHub, and Google Workspace, so you can focus on building AI experiences rather than integration details.
This eliminates the challenge of maintaining your own MCP servers and handling complex authentication flows. It is suitable for integrating apps with gated resource access.

LangChain is a framework, while MCP is a protocol. Framework, you risk vendor locking, this is not the case with protocols. As long as you follow the protocol guidelines, you will be fine. Even LangChain can adopt MCP as a standard for building stateful agents.

Isnâ€™t it easier to call tools directly instead of jumping through hoops? Yes, but a protocol ensures that developers define and call tools uniformly, making it easier to develop both clients(host apps) and servers (integrations).

Again, the goal is to reduce as much developmental overhead as possible. For example, Cursor developers will focus solely on client implementation, while Linear will concentrate on server implementation. As long as both comply with the base protocol standard (which we described in detail), both are good.
Yes, to connect your AI assistants with third-party apps for real-world actions, MCP is the easiest and most convenient way to do it.

It is basically a bridge that lets AI step outside its training data and interact with real-world data in real-time.
Before MCP, AI was powerful but limited to its training set. MCP servers let AI models fetch real-time data and also take action on it.
For example, if you ask AI, â€œWhatâ€™s the stock market price of Meta right now?â€ it couldnâ€™t tell you because itâ€™s probably stuck with data from 2021.
By now, you should already have a bit of an idea of what MCP allows an AI model to do. But if not, let me clarify with an example.

It allows AI to connect to external data sources and be more context-aware, and that is super powerful. Think of it as an upgrade that makes the AI go from â€œI can only tell you from what I have been taughtâ€ to â€œI can fetch live data, book your flights, and maybe even order pizza for you.â€
Notice, it not only gives access to real-time data but also allows the AI to perform actions (make changes) to your system.

p: While everyone is occupied with the next best frontier model, the smaller models often get ignored. Yes, we are calling 32b models small language models now (My 2021 brain wouldn't be able to comprehend this).

You can effectively run these models in your local setup without quantizing it to the bones. A personal LLM can be helpful if you do not want to hand over personal data to BIG AI. Another upside is that smaller language models can drastically reduce your bills if you're a developer building apps.

Recently, Qwen, Mistral and Google launched QwQ 32b (a reasoning model), Mistral small 24b, and Gemma 27b (a base model). Although they have different architectures, they have scores comparable to Deepseek r1 in the Lmsys leaderboard. Gemma is even scoring more than QwQ despite being a base model.

I'm not a big fan of leaderboards, as I am still sure Deepseek r1 with 671B parameters will always be far superior in general tasks. But I'd love to see how these three compare. QwQ even has scores on par with Deepseek r1 on multiple benchmarks.
So, the base assumption here is that the models will underperform R1, and anything above that will add a point in the models' favour.
I have used the OpenRouter hosted models for this comparison. You can also compare QwQ-32b with Reka Flash.
QwQ overall is the best of the lot.
It leads in Coding, reasoning, and math, though has an inclination to think and talk a lot.
Gemma 3 is second, the vibes are great and solid model but with restrictive Gemma license.
Mistral small 3.1 is a good model, can go through most simple tasks but pales in comparison to QwQ.
If you were to choose a single model for local hosting QwQ 32b is the one.
When comparing these three models, the answer is not apparent if you want to jump straight to the conclusion. QwQ leads on coding sometimes better than Deepseek r.
If it is for coding, go with the QwQ 32B model. For anything else, Gemma 3 is equally excellent and should get your work done. Mistral is a distant third here.
Alibaba released this new model in the first week of March with a 32B model size, claiming it is capable of rivalling Deepseek R1, which has a 671 B model size.
This marks their initial step in scaling RL (Reinforcement Learning) to improve the modelâ€™s reasoning capabilities.
Below is the benchmark they have made public to highlight QwQ-32Bâ€™s performance compared to another leading model, Deepseek R1.
Now, this is looking a lot more interesting, especially with the comparison they have done with a model that is about 20x their size, Deepseek R1.
Gemma 3 is Googleâ€™s new open-source model based on Gemini 2.0. The model comes in 4 different sizes (1B, 4B, 12B, and 27B), but thatâ€™s not interesting.
It is said to be the â€œmost capable model you can run on a single GPU or TPU.â€ This directly means that it is capable of running on resource-limited devices.
It supports a 128K context window and over 140 languages, and itâ€™s mainly built for reasoning tasks.
Letâ€™s see if that really is the case and how good this model is at reasoning.
This is the entrant from Mistral with multimodal understanding, and an expanded context window of up to 128k tokens. Mistral has also claimed to have beaten Gemma 27b and GPT-40 mini.
In this section, I will test the coding capabilities of all three models on animation and a tricky LeetCode question.
Prompt: Create a JavaScript simulation of a rotating 3D sphere made up of letters. The closest letters should be brighter, while the ones farthest away should appear grey.
You can find the code it generated here: Link
Here's the output of the program:
The output we got from QwQ is entirely insane. Everything I asked for, from the animation to the letters spinning and their colours changing. Everything is on point. So good!
It does not wholly follow my prompt. Something seemed to be happening, but I asked for a 3D sphere with a ring spinning with the alphabet.
Knowing this model isnâ€™t good at coding, we at least got something working, though!
This was awful; it only showed a blank screen.

It got it mostly correct and implemented exactly what I asked for. No doubt about that, but compared to the output from the QwQ 32B model, this really does not seem to compare in terms of overall output.

In this section, the QwQ 32B model is undoubtedly the winner. It crushed our coding tests with the animation. QwQ 32B beats Deepseek R1 here. On the other hand both Gemma and Mistral were subpar. So, one point to QwQ.
For this one, letâ€™s do a quick LeetCode check with a super hard LeetCode question to see how these models solve a tricky LeetCode question with an acceptance rate of 14.4%: Strong Password Checker.
Considering this is a tricky LeetCode question, I have little to no hope with all three models as they are not as good as some other code models like Claude 3.7.
If you want to see how Claude 3.7 compares to some top models like Grok 3 and o3-mini-high, check out this blog post:
Claude 3.7 Sonnet vs. Grok 3 vs. o3-mini-high: Coding comparison
Damn, Qwen got the answer correctly. It also wrote the entire code in O(N) time complexity, which is within the expected time complexity.
It would have been decent if I had to compare the code quality. The model documents everything adequately. So, the model has a lot of potential.
Though it took a lot of time to think, the working answer really matters here.
Okay, Gemma 3 falls short here. It got almost halfway there with 39/54 test cases passing, but such faulty code does not even help. It is better not to bother generating code than to code it poorly.
But considering this model is open-source, has just 27B parameters, and operates on a single GPU or TPU, thatâ€™s one thing we can think.
It couldnâ€™t clear it. Got 19 test cases right.
In my previous test, where I compared Deepseek R1 with Grok 3, Deepseek R1 failed pretty badly. If youâ€™d like to take a look:
Cool, it almost got it with 51/54 test cases passing. But even a single test case failure will result in an incorrect submission, so yeah, hard luck here for Deepseek R1.

The result is evident when comparing these three models on two coding questions. QwQ 32B model is the winner. Gemma 3 27B did try it, but it is not something you would want to use for advanced coding. Mistral too failed, so two points for QwQ.
Here, we will check the reasoning capabilities of both models.
Letâ€™s start with a pretty simple question (not tricky at all), which requires a bit of common sense. But letâ€™s see if these models have it.
I wanted to test if the models can parse what is asked and reason just what is needed or deal with everything given. This is similar to asking what it is: 10000*3456*0*1234.

Prompt: You start with 14 apples. Emma takes three but gives back 2. You drop seven and pick up 4. Leo takes four and offers 5. You take one apple from Emma and trade it with Leo for 3 apples, then give those 3 to Emma, who hands you an apple and an orange. Zara takes your apple and gives you a pear. You trade the pear with Leo for an apple. Later, Zara trades an apple for an orange and swaps it with you for another apple. How many pears do you have? Answer me just what is asked.
As you can see, we provide all the unnecessary background with apples and oranges, but Pear, which is just what is asked, is at the end with one single trade, resulting in us having zero pears.
You can find its reasoning here: Link
You can find its reasoning here: Link.
It calculated all the situations and returned the total pear count in just a few seconds. I canâ€™t complain much here.
The response was super quick; I was utterly impressed by this model.

It thought for about a minute and did come up with the answer. It was expected that it would come up with the correct answer, but I just wanted to see if it could give me the answer to what I asked without doing all the unnecessary calculations with apples and oranges. Sadly, it also failed.

With this question, I wasnâ€™t looking for the correct answer; even a first-grader could answer it. I was trying to see if these LLMs could filter out all the unnecessary details and answer just what was asked, but sadly, all of them failed, even though I added this sentence: â€œAnswer me just what is asked.â€ at the end of the prompt. So, 0 to all.

Prompt: A bald, skinny woman lives on the 78th floor of an apartment. On sunny days, she takes the elevator up to the 67th floor and walks the rest. On rainy days, she takes the elevator straight up to her floor. Why does she take the elevator to her floor on rainy days?

The question is tricky as I have included similar unnecessary details to distract the LLMs from easily finding the answer. The answer is that the woman is short and canâ€™t reach the button in the summer, but she carries an umbrella that she can use to press the elevator button higher.
The answer has nothing to do with the girl being bald or skinny.
It took a seriously long time, 311 seconds (~5.2 minutes), to figure out what that had to do with her being bald and skinny, but I am super impressed with the response.
The way it explained its thought process is imposing. You should take a look as well.
Itâ€™s fair to say that QwQ 32B really got it correct and explained everything perfectly.
I was shocked by Gemma 3, within a couple of seconds, it got it correct. This model looks at reasoning tasks. So far, I am super impressed with this Google open-source model.
We know how good Deepseek is at reasoning tasks, so itâ€™s not really surprising that it got the answer correct.
It took some time to come up with the answer, thinking straight for about 72 seconds (~1.2 minutes), but I love the reasoning and thought process it uses every time.
It was really having a hard time understanding what the problem had to do with the woman being bald and skinny, but hey, thatâ€™s the reason I added it.
All the models got it right so one point to each. This wasnâ€™t particularly very hard question.
Looking at the reasoning questions answered by all three models, I was convinced that both of these models should also pass the math questions.
Prompt: At what time between 5.30 and 6 will the hands of a clock be at right angles?
Find the CoT trace here: Link
Apart from the coding questions, Gemma 3 got this one correct. What a tiny yet powerful model this is.
I had already compared Deepseek R1 and Grok 3. It is clear how good Deepseek is at Mathematics, so I had high hopes for this model.
As usual, this question was also answered correctly. It took some time and thought, but it did.
Gemma 3 27B does it in no time, and the other two models, QwQ 32B and Deepseek R1, crush this with proper reasoning. While Mistral failed by a bit. So, one point to all except Mistral.
Prompt: How many different ways can the letters of the word â€˜MATHEMATICSâ€™ be arranged so that the vowels always come together?
Itâ€™s a classic Mathematics question for an LLM, so letâ€™s see how these three models perform.
After thinking for 552 seconds (~9.2 minutes), yes, it took that long to come up with the answer, but as always, it also nailed this question.
All its reasoning feels super long and boring, but if it gets the job done, then thatâ€™s a good side to it. The QwQ 32B model looks solid and crushes all the questions.
It was spot on. Itâ€™s amazing how quickly and accurately this model gives responses. Google did good work on this model, and thereâ€™s no doubt about that.
After thinking for around 132 seconds (~2.2 minutes), it came up with the correct answer,

The answer is obvious this time as well. All three of our models got it perfectly, with perfect explanation and reasoning. For a question this tough, itâ€™s a super impressive response to get back from all three models, but to me, Gemma 3 27B just stands out. What a lightweight, solid model. Even Mistral got it right this time. So, a point for all.
The new Qwen is really impressive, so is Gemma but only problem is with the Gemma open-source license. Qwen seem to found a sweet spot between size and performance.
It will be exciting to see what they come up with next.

Gemma 3 is definitely a solid base model. They have perfected the art of distilling large models (Gemini 2.0) to smaller models like Gemma and Flash. Mistral rather felt under whelming, it didn't feel close to Qwen and Gemma.
For coding tasks, QwQ 32B is better.
For reasoning, and math again Qwen is better. But Gemma is not bad.
Gemma and Mistral small also comes with image input support, so that'a big plus.
QwQ and Mistral comes with more permissible license Apache 2.0, while Gemma has Google Gemma license, a tad bit restrictive.
So, overall QwQ 32b wins hands down, Deepseek r1 like performance in compact size.

p: Deepseek v3 o324, a new checkpoint, has been released by Deepseek in silence, with no marketing or hype, just a tweet, a model card and a 641GB MIT-licensed open-weight base modelâ€”very Deepseek-like. This, paired with Gemini 2.5 and Chatgpt image generation, caused the entire launch to go under the carpet.

Thinking that they released potentially the best base model and have made a single tweet so far is beyond comprehension; itâ€™s time the Whales hire a great PR team. They could name it Deepseek v3.5 and couldâ€™ve wiped another round of billions from Bigtech stocks.

The v3 was released three months ago, around Christmas. Now, we have another base model with increased capability. From the initial vibes, it seems we finally have the Sonnet 3.5 at home (not literally, but you got my point). I blogged about Deepseek v3, and it was a great model and on par with GPT-4o, but this model is a massive upgrade over the last one.

v3 matched GPT-4o, and v3 0324 is on par with Claude 3.5 Sonnet. Eating into the moat of most closed models: A comment from HackerNews perfectly summarizes this, â€œSorry, try again with a better moatâ€.
RL training with GRPO for better reasoning
But how much improvement over others
If you've somewhere else to be, here's a short summary.
It's a massive upgrade over the original v3.
Slightly bigger than v3 but with an MIT license.
Better reasoning, code generation, and a better understanding of user intention thanks to RL training with GRPO.
Performs better than Claude 3.7 Sonnet on many tasks that you would care
Can outperform Claude 3.5 Sonnet on many tasks still, but you may find 3.5 to be better at cases.
It's MIT-licensed, freely available, allows you to opt out of training, and is super cheap.
The best base LLM considering the price to performance.

Unlike the last v3, which had a custom v3 license, the new Deepseek v3 checkpoint comes with an MIT license. The model also has 685b parameters compared to 671b in the earlier v3 model. It should follow the architecture as the original v3, Deepseek Mixture of Experts (MoE) and Multi-head Latent Attention (MLA).
Some of the things that have been improved over the previous model collated from Huggingface
More aesthetically pleasing websites and game fronts

Some benchmarks matter more and are better predictors of a modelâ€™s capabilities. Not to underestimate the above benchmarks, private benchmarks often give a better picture of models' usability in the real world.
And Deepseek v3 0324 is doing exceedingly well in them as well.
On Xeophonâ€™s private benchmark, Deepseek v3 0324 is now the best non-reasoning model, even beating Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
The model came second to Claudeâ€™s 3.5 Sonnet on Paul Gauthierâ€™s Aider benchmark.

On the KCores LLM arena,Â which tests LLMs for real-world coding performance, Deepseek v3 0324 has surpassed Claude 3.7 Sonnet and is only belowÂ Claude 3.5 Sonnet and Claude 3.7 Sonnet (thinking). To think an MIT-licenced model is outperforming the recently released
The Deepseek v3 0324 made a massive 2x jump on the Misguided Attention eval. This is rather impressive, and it isÂ the top non-reasoning model.

As there are no official ARC-AGI results yet, Youtuber YJxAI is doing live testing (as of writing this blog post) on the public ARC-AGI dataset. The 0324 scores 28% on ARC-AGIâ€”above Grok 3 and Gemini 2.0 Pro but below Sonnets 3.5 and 3.7.

During testing, it became evident that Deepseek v3 0324 exhibits signs of reasoning capabilities much better than previous base models, perhaps because most mainline models from Deepseek after Math are RL-trained with GRPO.
What is interesting here is the approach to solving this question by Deepseek v3 0324 and Claude 3.5 and 3.7 Sonnet.
The response format is similar to that of any reasoning model CoT. Here are Claude 3.7's CoT traces, which resemble how Deepseek v3 0324 responded.
And this is Deepseek r1's response.
Despite not being reasoning models, the models have been RL-trained for better reasoning performance.
In comparison, here's the response from a non-reasoning models

The Deepseek v3 0324's responses are closer to a reasoning model than other base models, and I think this is significant. A base model can reason on par with the reasoning model with a fraction of tokens, and the cost is crazy.

Within hours of its release, Awni Hannun made a 4-bit quantised model run on a 512 GB MacBook M3 ultra at 20 tok/sec via mlx-lm and this mlx-community/DeepSeek-V3-0324-4bit 4-bit quantisation, which reduces the on-disk size to 352 GB.
If you have the machine, you can run it using Simon Willison's LLM MLX.
You can soon run it using Ollama, though they don't have the checkpoint yet.
The most significant indicator of model performance is seeing people building interesting stuff using it.

Reddit UserÂ Cpicd found Deepseek v3 0324 outperforming Claude 3.5 Sonnet in his personal code creativity benchmark. He asked the model to "Write a raytracer that renders an interesting scene with many colourful light sources in Python."
The new Deepseek has visibly improved from its predecessor and is on par with the Sonnets.
Akhaiq from HuggingFace made a 3JS game in the single prompt.
Parul Pandey created a water molecule movement simulation, where molecules form and break hydrogen bonds with temperature adjustments.
